dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAUD DOWLEY, (32) an odd, impish little creature, with hu saucers for eyes, is lying on the tall, overgrown grass staring up at the sky, smoking a cigarette. Her fingers a gnarled, her knuckles swollen with arthritis. A shadow repeatedly moves across her face and leaves it. The shadow is from an old swing made of rope and wood, dangling from the branch of a tree. The swing is swaying back and forth. As it slows down, Maud reaches up and giv it another push. She keeps staring at the sky, blowing he smoke towards the sky and watching as it blends into the clouds above. She stares at the clouds curiously, suddenl finding shapes and objects: A bunny rabbit. A steam engin Kittens. AUNT IDA (55), a sturdy, robust woman comes out, carrying mop and bucket. She is wearing an apron and a scarf aroun her head. Her sleeves are rolled up passed her elbows. She's heavily into her spring cleaning. Beads of sweat ru down her forehead. Maud picks herself up from the ground and takes a seat on the swing. Her feet dangling, unable to reach the ground. Ida hurries past Maud, a woman on a mission. The clothesline is filled with sheets, billowing about in the wind. The fence is lined with hooked rugs, out for freshening. Aunt Ida chucks the water from the bucket off to the side of the house. She takes the mop and starts to whack the rugs. Little clouds of dust appear with each wh

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Look at that, tsk tsk. The dust is going on the sheets. Ida takes the sheets off the line piling them up in her a Maud chucks her cigarette butt, gets up and starts to hel She takes the armload of sheets from Ida.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I got it. But then Maud gets tangled in a sheet still on the line, stumbles. She drops a sheet.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Maud. I'll have to rewash it now. It's easier if I do it alone, you're too awkward. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ida takes the sheets from her and heads into the house. Maud sits back down on the swing - discouraged. But then, she leans back, stares up at the clouds, as the move swiftly across the sky. The rabbits in the clouds ar almost bunny-hopping their way across the sky. Maud gets up and walks towards the house. As she stands o the veranda, she looks out on the landscape in wonder Then she lights up another cigarette....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud sits at the table, while Ida brings her tea and bisc into the austere dining room.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Here you go. Would you like jam?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That'd be nice. As Ida leaves the dining room:

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I can get it myself Aunt Ida. Moments later, she places the jam down in front of her. A Ida fusses around the dining room:

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Your brother is coming by tomorrow. Maud looks up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Why? Is he taking me back home?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: He's moving to Halifax. So he's dropping off a few of your things.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: If Charles and his wife are moving to Halifax, the house'll be empty. I can live there and take care of it. Irene says nothing. Maud takes a sip of her hot tea and i slips from her hand, spilling everywhere. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ow.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Stay there, I'll clean it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I can do it.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: I'll clean it. Irene rushes to grab a cloth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is standing in the mirror, fixing her hair, a little smile on her face.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'll be down in a minute, okay? Her suitcase is on the bed, with her belongings packed ne inside. She struggles to put the last bobby pin in her ha then grabs her belongings, and hurries out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CHARLES DOWLEY (37), Maud's handsome brother, is leaning against the door frame as Ida brings in his tea.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I can't stay long.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: At least stay for a cup of tea and a bit of cake.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: So has she been out, looking for trouble?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: So far, no. She keeps to herself. She's been asking to go home.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Did you tell her? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Not yet. I thought it best you do it. By now, Maud is standing in the doorway, having overheard the last bit of this conversation. She tries to hide her nervous concern with a smile.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Maud stands awkwardly, shy and nervous in front of her opposing brother.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Hi Charles. Nice to see you. Sizing him up:

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my, that's a good jacket you're wearing, it's a good fit. You're always such a spiffy dresser. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can't tell the difference between a rag and a ball gown. She chuckles, nervously. Then:

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So? You've come to take me home? He shifts on his feet, and says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's the big secret?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: It's business. Financial matters.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Well, I'm a natural at math. Remember, I used to double check your numbers when you were in school?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I don't have much time, I've got to be going, but I wanted to drop off a few things. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He points to a little stack of things: books, photographs and old blanket.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Lordy. You cleared out my room. Why?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Because I sold my house.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What house. Our house?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: It was my house. Mom left it to me. I sold it and I'm moving to Halifax with the band. Maud is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You can't sell that house. I woulda moved back there. I'd be more than happy to have my own place, I'd look after it --

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: You can't look after yourself, let alone a house, and a yard, and bills.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'd get a job, or something.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Job doing what?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I don't know, something.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I'm sorry Maud. It's gone. He smiles tightly, then heads towards the door. Maud foll him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Did you spend all the money they left behind? Because I haven't seen any of that either.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: They didn't leave it for you Maud. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: We both know mother would have expected you to look after me.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: She also would have expected you to behave like a decent girl. But you didn't. He keeps going towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Wait. Charles.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Maud, come get your tea.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Charles! He turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Good-bye sister. He leaves. Maud watches out the door, a little stunned. Ida sees she is upset.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: He's a busy man, Maud. Maud fights back tears.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know. Maud takes the package and goes back into her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is sitting on the swing, looking through the content of the package of her things: photos, trinkets. A photogr of her as a little girl with her cat Fluffy. Some old pai brushes and paints. Melancholy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is still sitting on the edge of her bed, the lights off. She's still waiting, waiting. She watches through th crack in the bottom of her bedroom door as the SHADOW of Aunt Ida's footsteps pass by her room. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Seconds later, the light from the hallway is turned off, the CLICK of a bedroom door being shut. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Moments later, Maud gets up and gently opens her bedroom door and sneaks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music pours out of the jazz club as Maud approaches, tryi to contain her excitment. She smiles at a couple who gigg their way out of the club, arms around each other. Maud gathers her nerve and heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside a jazz club, filled with people, the flame on a cigarette illuminates a dark corner... It is Maud, puffing on a cigarette, hiding from the crowd her eyes scouring the room. She has become an expert at being inconspicuous. She smokes with one hand, and with t other she fiddles with her sweater, pulling it up over he chin as she sways to the music. She spots a couple dancing. Studies them for a bit. She looks to another couple sitting at a table, talking intimately. She scours the room. Her eyes land on a group of women. She studies them with quiet admiration as they laugh. She takes note of one woman, DINA SHEA who is obviously pregnant. As she makes her way toward them, she bumps into a_ short, stubby, and bald MAN. Maud sees him, and her face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Not sure who was gonna knock over who. (quickly searching for what to say next) Mmmmm. You smell like turkey supper. In a good way. (giggles. ) He tries to make his way around her, but she stops him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love this music. Gets my feet going like a couple a hammers. He shoves her aside, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Christ, get out of my way. Who let you in here? He walks around her. She watches him for a moment, feelin the sting. But then moves on, with a hopeful determinatio (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 7A
dialogues.text: ee OF  7A.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Men everywhere. But she is completely invisible to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With the band now on break, Maud maneuvers her way throug the dark club. She is smaller than everyone else in the room, and mostly goes unnoticed. She's feeling discourage (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is about to give up and go home, until she sees Dina, the pregnant woman, sitting on a bar stool by herself. Ma sidles up next to her.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Bet you're seven months. Maud smiles at the woman. She's very attractive, even tho she's tired. She's smoking a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you started nesting? Getting your house all fixed up nice and cozy?

dialogues.speaker: DINA
dialogues.text: Yeah, a little. Maud smiles, looking somewhat envious.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: If you're looking to hire a sitter, I'm looking for work. Dina smiles politely.

dialogues.speaker: DINA
dialogues.text: We won't be hiring a sitter.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No harm in asking. Awkward silence for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not often you sees a lady in your condition out at night.

dialogues.speaker: DINA
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, my old man is the guy with the trumpet, I like to make sure he gets home alright, if you know what I mean. Maud smiles and leans in.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You love it when it kicks? Fluttering like a fish in a bowl. Maud stares at the woman's belly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The heartburn, that's no fun. And the trips to the bathroom. Maud laughs to herself - as if remembering. The woman isn sure how to take Maud.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh my, worth it though. Since Maud isn't going away, the woman finally engages.

dialogues.speaker: DINA
dialogues.text: How old is your baby?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't have a baby. The woman is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Died at birth.

dialogues.speaker: DINA
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I didn't see her, but they told me she was really deformed. Sad. Then she looks at Dina, who is mid-puff of a cigarette, somewhat disinterested. Maud can't resist:

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Always worried it was cuz I smoked. Dina stops inhaling.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Prob'ly wasn't. Still, you never know. Dina hands her cigarette to Maud. Maud takes it, takes a big inhale. She smiles at the woman.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (referring to the cigarette) Thanks.  10 11 10. INT. AUNT IDAвЂ™S HOUSE - UPSTAIRS HALL - NIGHT 10 Maud sneaks her way back to her room, tip toeing up the stairs, carefully trying not to make noise. All the light are off in the house. But as she arrives at the top -- Aunt Ida is standing there. A stern look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: You better not tell me you were out at that club.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I wasn't going to tell you that.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I was at the club. But I wasn't gonna tell you. She smiles. Ida is pissed.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I couldn't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: You get in trouble again, I'm tossing you out on your duff. Do you understand me?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'm only looking to meet friends.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: That's what you said last time, and look where that got you. In your room. Maud keeps her head down and walks to her room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is standing in the doorway as Ida and the Presbyteri Women's Group gather for morning prayer

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Prepare our hearts and minds, O God, to receive your Word. Silence in us any voice but your own, that, hearing, we may obey your will through Jesus Christ our Lord. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ALL WOMEN
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: DONNA
dialogues.text: Lord, open our hearts and minds by the power of your Spirit that we may hear your living Word as the Scriptures are read and interpreted.

dialogues.speaker: ALL WOMEN
dialogues.text: Amen. Maud tries to get Ida's attention.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Pssst. Psssst. Aunt Ida notices her, but it's her turn to pray. She glar at Maud while she says her next bit.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Speak to us, O Lord, as you open to us the Scriptures and interpret them to us for this day.

dialogues.speaker: ALL WOMEN
dialogues.text: Amen. Then everyone looks to Maud.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I wanted to get your tea ready for after your prayer but you're out of tea bags. And you need flour

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Not now, Maud.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Do you want me to run to the store?

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: I'll do it later.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Let me do it, I'll take the wagon.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Fine, fine. (to the women) Sorry about that. Maud walks out the door.  12 13 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud walks up the street, pulling a little wooden wagon. She is somewhat hunched and walks with a little limp, so moves slowly. As she passes by one house, she admires a family playing with their LITTLE GIRL in a pink dress. She smiles to her as the little girl squeals over something. She continues on, and gets many strange looks from people the street, but she does her best to ignore them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud walks into the general store, her wagon left outside She immediately heads towards the aisles. Her eyes pour over the shelves. MR. MCDOUGAL, the storekeeper, nods at her.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCDOUGAL
dialogues.text: Can I help you with something Miss Dowley?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I need a sack of flour.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCDOUGAL
dialogues.text: You won't find it on the shelves, I have that over here.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I know. I like to look at the cans. All the different colours. It's pretty. She smiles at him - he gives an awkward smile back, not knowing how to take her. As Maud walks through the aisles, the bell on the door ri as someone else enters the store. Maud continues to study the shelves.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCDOUGAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well look who's gracing me with their presence today. What can I do for you, Everett?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (quietly) I'm looking for a woman. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCDOUGAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: By now, Maud's interest is piqued. She gazes around the corner, catching a look at EVERETT LEWIS (45), a tall, ga curmudgeonly man. Everett shifts on his feet, awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: A housemaid, a housemaid. Mr. McDougal looks at him, not sure if he understands.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCDOUGAL
dialogues.text: Not the kind a thing we sell. Everett gives him an angry look.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Am I an idiot? I want to put upa sign. A whadayacall. I need you to write it. Everett hands him a square of paper. The store keeper loo at him skeptically for a moment, then takes up a pen. Eve dictates.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: "Looking for a housemaid. Must bring their own..." Everett struggles to find the word.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's the word I'm looking for?

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCDOUGAL
dialogues.text: Sense of humour?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: "Cleaning tools". That's good enough. Sign my name onto it. Say my house is over the road in Marshalltown.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCDOUGAL
dialogues.text: You really need a housekeeper at that little house?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What does size got to do with anything? You don't got that big of a store, and you got three or four people works here. I need a hand, I need a hand. Everett takes the note and heads toward the back of the s As he goes, MAUD tip toes along to continue to observe. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett POSTS the sign. CLOSE ON: the sign - "Looking for a housemaid, must bring cleaning supplies. Contact Everett Lewis, Main Rd, Marshalltown. Everett leaves without another word. After the bell on th door jangles, indicating Everett's departure, Maud approa the bulletin board. She looks up and sees Everett's sign: Looking for a housemaid... She studies it with great interest. She reaches up to get the note, but it's too high. Maud sees a stool, and she drags it across the floor, climbs up on it. She reaches once more for the piece of paper, this time she snatches Then Maud runs to the door and watches as Everett pushes wheelbarrow down the street. She continues to watch him a he heads off in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett wheels a wheelbarrow along a winding, lonely road Dogs are barking loudly in the near distance. This alerts Everett, causing him to speed up. He approaches a TINY HOUSE that sits on the side of the r His yard is littered with junk. His two dogs are tied on outside a woodshed. The dogs are both very agitated, aimi their attentions at the house.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What's going on? Everett creeps over to his house carefully once he sees h door is swinging opened.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I said who's there? The INTRUDER bolts out of the house, and makes a run for

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey! What did you take! Everett chases him up the road. But he's not fast enough the man heads off through the back woods.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lord Jesus. Everett debates continuing the chase, but realizes it's useless. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett stops chasing him and stomps back to the house, a glares at the dogs. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What good are you if you don't scare anything away? Useless mutts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is taking his money, and stashing little bits in different places - a bill inside a mug, a few coins ina jar. Then he lifts up the cold storage trap door in the floor and hides more money in a tin can, then stuffs it i the cold storage and closes the hatch once more. He grumbles to himself. His 13x13 house is cluttered and messy. Lit by a lantern, and heated with a wood stove. After Everett finishes stashing his money, he climbs the ladder up to his loft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett pulls off his two socks and lays them side by sid dangling over the bedpost. He climbs under the cover and tucks himself down in his bed. He reaches towards the lan and turns down the flame until the room goes black. He lays there, in the dark, a tiny bit of moonlight illuminating his face as his heavy breathing attempts to settle into a rhythm. He closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide, landscape shot of the fields and landscape surrou Everett's little house, which sits small and alone among huge, overcast sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is alone in a small, dimly lit shack, stoking the fire in the potbelly stove. It's quiet, not a sound excep for the hiss and dull roar of the fire. As he sips on his tea, he picks up a little toy tin badge and tries to fix the broken clip on the back, that has co loose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is now dressed in her Sunday best, wearing a dainty pair of shoes, as she makes her way up the road. To one side, a large, old Poor House, DIGBY COUNTY ORPHAN set back from the road. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 15A.
dialogues.text: A few young children, dressed in modest grey clothing, ru about on the field playing a game of tag. passes them. She smiles as she (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then she looks across the field, and pauses to watch the COWS grazing.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Hello big boys. (whistles) Hello there. She smiles at them, and keeps going. Finally, she comes upon Everett's lone, small, gloomy hou The yard is filled with junk, wood piles, and an old Mode Ford in the driveway. She stops, and looks around, a little bewildered. Then sh sees the wheelbarrow parked outside the house. She gather her courage and heads towards the door. The dogs see her approaching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett continues to fiddle with the tin badge, when he h the dogs start barking outside.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello little pups. Hello little pups. Everett is startled by the sound of a voice. He stands frozen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud looks down at the dogs, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Whatcha got on your feet? Woolens? Are you wearing a pair of woolens? Down. Down. Ouch. The dogs are barking more aggressively. Everett sneaks ov to the window, tries to steal a look He can't quite make her out.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think I'm the enemy, do ya? Dying to chew on my limbs, aren't you? Want my jacket? Take it, creature, you can have it. Good boy. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON EVERETT as he creeps over to the other side, standing next to the wall, and peers out the other window. No sign of her at all. Then suddenly, she KNOCKS on the door Everett jumps. He hesitates for a moment before opening i Maud looks up at him with her two huge bright brown eyes and smiles widely.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm Maud. Dowley. Her nose is running from the cold.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Dowley.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That's right. She sniffs again. He just stares at her. She continues.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was, I got the ad at the store the one you posted, looking for a house maid, IвЂ™m answering it. He looks at her distastefully.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m looking for a woman. Maud giggles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What do you think I am? Everett sizes up the tiny, odd looking, misshapen woman a he walks past her, and heads towards his shed.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t know. She follows him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I walked here from Digby. My feet are knobbed off. He gathers an armload of wood. She huddles her arms close to her body for warmth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: WouldnвЂ™t mind a cup a tea, you can tell me what your lookinвЂ™ for He looks at her skeptically, then jerks his head for her come in. She follows him into the house. INT. EVERETT'S HOUSE вЂ” CONTINUOUS 22 He tries to watch her out of the corner of his eye, as sh takes the place in, a grin on her face. Suddenly, Everett is more aware of his rundown, filthy little house. The ai is thick with heat and smoke from the stove. Every surfac is filled with clutter and dust.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: So...youвЂ™re looking for a cleaner. A live in?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I dunno about live in. Maud looks around the one room house.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Gonna say. YouвЂ™re lookinвЂ™ for a small woman. Maud gives him a big smile as she refers to herself.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Mom always joked that I was a size вЂњtinyвЂќ. Maud chuckles. Everett doesnвЂ™t.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was hoping you were looking for a live in just the same. Everett is surprised at her boldness. Maud walks towards chair. She sits, a polite smile on her face. She looks around some more, вЂњadmiringlyвЂќ.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So this is all yours? This house? Everett can't help but boast.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Used to belong to Captain John Ryan. I moved it all the way from the wharf to here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 CONTINUED: 19.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Lordy. You own this land too?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Was given to me by the Orphanage for all the work I does for them.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You must do some good work.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Guess how many Ox it took to move her here? Maud smiles, glad to be having conversation.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Two?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Seven Oxen. Everett stokes the fire, tosses another chunk of wood in top of it. Silence for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Be nice for you. Have someone give you a hand around here. He says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, be hard to do it all.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I been doing it all my whole life.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Every business man needs staff.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well, you got that right, Madam.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What sort of stuff do you do?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I sell fish, I sell chopped wood does work for the Orphanage down the road -

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Lordy. How do you keep it straight? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22  CONTINUED: (2) 20. 22

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I've got a lot on my plate. A lot of valuable things in this house too. With nobody here all day, there's always someone lurking about, trying to rob me.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Well, IвЂ™m good at scaring off people. She chuckles. He doesn't. She looks around once more.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd like the job. Everett hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: YouвЂ™re a bit older than I was picturing. Maud laughs uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: They says I get on like IвЂ™m twelve, SO... She pulls the sweater up over her chin, an obvious nervou tick. Everett gets an old dirty mug, pours a bit of water in it, swishes it around and gives the water a flick. It sprays across Maud. She giggles again.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, there you go. No need for a wash tomorrow. She giggles again. He doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just joshin'. Everett sticks a teabag in the mug and takes it over to t stove. He splashes some boiling water from the kettle int the cup and brings it over to Maud.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh thank you.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Are you sick or something? CanвЂ™t bring in a cripple, next thing I'd be lookinвЂ™ after YOU.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maud smirks.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Nah, I was just born funny. I can do the work of five women.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Born in Ohio, Yarmouth County, but I lives with my Aunt over in Digby. Aunt Ida. Ida Dowley on Point Road? Everett gets a look of recognition in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: That bag of wind. Is that where you live? She kickin' you out?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Lordy, no. She'd never do that, she's too Christian. She's good as gold, but a woman needs to have her own life, right? Her own purpose, her own home - not that this'd be my home either, it's yours - She sips her tea. The dogs are now curled up at her feet. She continues to nervously ramble:

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Never had dogs growing up, donвЂ™t know why, Momma always loved em. I did too, but they made my brother sneeze. I had cats. WerenвЂ™t allowed in the house, but oh my I love cats. Everett stares blankly at Maud, making her more nervous, which makes her talk more.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We had one, Tom. Big ole cat. Some fat. Used to sit on the ledge of my window. She sips her tea.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He went missing. Sad. Likes dogs though. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett gets up, opens his door. He gives his foot one st the dog jumps up and obediently runs out the door. Maud lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got an ashtray? Everett points to the floor

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Flick em there. She does.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Many people apply for the job?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You finished your tea? Maud looks at her almost empty mug.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Might as well say. She swallows the last of it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, you do need the help, I can see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett practically shoos Maud out the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Long walk home alone. Kids'll throw rocks at me again. Buggers.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Who throws rocks at you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: People don't like a different sort of person. I don't care. Be easier if I wasn't alone, but... She looks up at him, hopefully. Everett doesn't know what he is supposed to do.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: S'pose I can walk you home. I'm doing my rounds anyway. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That'd be nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett and Maud walk along the road in silence together, the dog running along beside them. Everett pushes his fis trolley. Maud covers her mouth with her sweater. The two make an o pair as they walk along the road. Everett is almost twice the height of Maud. Maud walks ev more awkwardly than usual. She smiles up at Everett.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: It's a lot of work to break in a new shoe. My heels are galled off. She giggles.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: This is as far as I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. (thinking fast) Oh, could you come by our house tomorrow? She needs a good piece of fish.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Aunt Ida. She told me to tell you she wanted to buy fish. Maud smiles. He heads back towards his house.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow. She heads back towards her house, filled with new hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is standing by, waiting for Frank to finish split the fish. Arms folded, shifting from one foot to the next

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You getting paid by the hour or the fish. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 25 CONTINUED: 23A.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: You want it to be clean.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I don't care either way, just give it to me. He takes the fish from Frank and puts it in his wheelbarr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is looking out her window when she sees Everett approaching the house with fish. She picks up a feather duster and hurries towards the door, opens it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 24A
dialogues.text: 25  25 26 CONTINUED: 24. 25

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh, hello. You caught me in the middle of my chores. I'm sweating buckets. He holds out the fish.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Aunt Ida. There's someone here to see you. Aunt Ida rounds the corner and shows up at the door. When she sees Everett she bristles.

dialogues.speaker: AUNT IDA
dialogues.text: Never thought I'd see you on this step again. Everett stands there, holding a stick with several fish o it, dangling from their gills. He shifts on his feet, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I thought you wanted fish.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Not from you I don't.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: She said you did. Plus you still owes me a nickel from the last time. Maud hurries off towards the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She comes back, wearing an apron, with a cloth in her han Making sure she is in Everett's full view, Maud starts to vigorously polish the furniture.

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t owe you anything.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Y-y-you do so, you owe me for that split fish.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I'm sure I paid you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You did NOT pay me. Suddenly Everett notices Maud cleaning in the background. Once she sees him look her way, she scrubs even harder.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: And the truth is it was fausty. So... Everett glares at Ida, angrily.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: The only thing fausty around here is you...plus you got a face like a prune and an arse like a sack a potatoes. Maud stifles a giggle. Ida is shocked. She slams the door on Everett. Maud hurri back into the dining room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And reaches her hand into Aunt Ida's change purse and swipes a nickel. She takes her hand out of the purse in t nick of time, as Ida walks into the room, all in a huff.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: The manners of a horse. Why would anyone talk to me like that? I'ma good Christian. She stomps through the house, paying zero attention to Ma as she passes. Maud walks out of the room... EXT. AUNT IDAвЂ™S HOUSE - FRONT PORCH -- DAY 28 ...And heads out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud looks up the road and sees Everett off in the distan pushing his wheelbarrow. She heads towards him. Several children scatter, giggling and screaming, when th see Everett coming. Everett embraces it.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: RUN! !!! Pile a monkeys. Oooga booga booga!!!! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett raises his arms and dances, makes as if he is goi to chase the children. They scurry off, TRULY terrified. Maud is amused. She hurries to catch up with him. He sees her coming and speeds up.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Wait. Hold on. He doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She got a mind like a sieve. She musta forgot. Wait. Hold up. He keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have something for you. This intrigues him. Without looking at her, he stops to wait until she catches up. She arrives by his side, winde

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here... A nickel. (catching her breath) Sorry about...Aunt Ida....she don't know it but...she's a bit...odd. He looks down at her big brown eyes. Her strange little face, beaming up at him. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Some job to keep up to your legs. She holds her hand out further

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here. Take it. She motions for him to take the nickel. He finally reache out and she drops the coin in his hand. He puts it in his pocket and says nothing. He keeps going.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When are you gonna make a decision?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I'm not in any rush. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I understand. So I should let you know, I do have another job offer. This catches his attention.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah. Cleaning a house over the road. Starting in a couple of days. She smiles. He looks displeased. He shifts doesn't.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But this house is big, really big.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Piff. Nothing worse than a big house.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I feel the same way. It's not cozy. Some people got too much money, you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Makes people lazy.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I likes a good hard worker myself. But oh well. That's it. I needa job now, so I'm going to have to take it. on his feet, wanting to say something. But he So she continues.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, yeah. Starts in two days. She laughs nervously.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who am I to complain? I loves a bit of work, so I should just be grateful. But you'll find someone else, I bet loads of women applied. She smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whoever you end up hiring, she's a lucky woman. Nice meeting you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett watches as Maud heads back towards Ida's house. A Maud walks away, she's grinning from ear to ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a bar of soap in his hand, Everett is waiting in lin with a bunch of boys, various ages. Each boy takes a few seconds to slap some water and soap on the face and hands then hurry off. Once they leave, Everett is alone. He pulls off his shirt then slowly starts to lather up his soap and begins to wa himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long table of boys, all of them eating. And among them, the tall, lanky and freshly cleaned Everett. Everyone is focused on their food. No attempts at interacting with th children, but comfortable just the same. MR. HILL (60) WALKS through the dining hall, nodding and smiling at the boys. He sees Everett and salutes him - a friendly gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett roots through a stack of junk, sorting things he deems useful and putting them in his wheelbarrow. Mr. Hill is clipping the weeds that are growing around th fence.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HILL
dialogues.text: Not much there worth anything Everett. Everett keeps sorting.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Might not be worth anything to you. He finds a piece of tar paper, throws it in his wheelbarr

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I've got to stock up on everything, because I keep getting robbed.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HILL
dialogues.text: Who's robbing you now?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Who's not robbing me. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Every time I turn around. No 29. matter where I hide my money, they sniff it out. Everett spits.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HILL
dialogues.text: I told you, open a bank account.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I'm not paying someone to hold my money.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HILL
dialogues.text: Weren't you thinking about hiring a woman?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah. But there's slim pickins applied for the job.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HILL
dialogues.text: Someone actually applied?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Maybe I'd be better off with one of those young fellas. They could look out for the house during the day.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HILL
dialogues.text: These kids are under ten. They can't stay home alone all day.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I did the work of ten men when I was his age. I cleaned this yard, up all the wood -

dialogues.speaker: MR. HILL
dialogues.text: chopped Yes, but you were here, around people. Your house is up the road in the middle of nowhere. Everett has finished loading his wheelbarrow. He starts t walk away.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everett, if someone applied for that job, hire them. Everett waves him off without looking. it's obvious that he's considering... But as he walks away, 32  33 34 35 36 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett straightens out his hair, as he sputters down the road, shaking his knee nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is helping Ida shaking out the sheets that cover the rarely used living room. I

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Shake it. You have to let a bit of air under it to get lift. Up. Up.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Lordy. Takes muscle, don't it?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Higher. Let me show you. Then suddenly, an impatient horn beeps repeatedly.

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is that racket? As the horn keeps beeping, Maud looks out the window. She sees that it's EVERETT. Maud heads towards the front door. Ida follows her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ida watches in horror as Maud makes her way down the side towards Everett.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: God almighty help save us all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud walks up to the truck, acting calm.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Nice day out. Everett doesn't bite with the small talk. He blurts it ou

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: S'pose I'll give you a try.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That'd be nice. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He stiffens up, and looks away.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well don't stand there all day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ida watches from the window. She looks up and down the ro in a panic, checking to see who else might be a witness t this. Maud leaves the truck and heads back towards the house. EverettвЂ™s truck stays parked outside the fence.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: God in heaven. Maud comes back in the house and walks right by Ida, igno her glare. Maud heads towards her bedroom, Ida follows.

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's going on? INT. AUNT IDA'S HOUSE - MAUDвЂ™S BEDROOM -- DAY 38 Maud is hurriedly packing up her things.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m gonna be his housemaid. Ida nearly chokes.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m a grown woman. I need to go off and have my own place.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: You canвЂ™t look after yourself, Maud.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I know you think that. Maud starts to pack her things in a bag, when Ida, ina desperate move, KNOCKS her belongings out of her hand. A hand mirror, a hair brush. She and Maud stare at each oth for a moment. Then Maud softens.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You been nice to take me in. Maud picks up her things and leaves the bedroom.  39 40 INT. AUNT IDAвЂ™S HOUSE - HALLWAY -- DAY As Maud walks through the house:

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'll make sure to tell everyone that you're a good Christian. IвЂ™ve been nothing but a scourge to you.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: You're determined to put a stain on our family name. Maud leaves though the front door. Ida follows Maud onto the veranda. EXT. AUNT IDAвЂ™S HOUSE - DAY 32. Maud keeps walking towards the truck, determined not to l back.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Think of your mother. What would she think if she were alive? This stops Maud for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Ma wanted me to have what everyone else had.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: That includes a bit of pride. Common sense. Dignity. She would be ashamed of you. Maud feels stung by this.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: If you leave you are not coming back. You know that, right? Maud looks at her for a moment, considering this. Then Everett "toots" the horn.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t got all day, woman. Maud turns and continues towards him. Everett gets out of the truck and takes her bags, throws them in the back 39 40  41 42 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud stares out the window as they drive down the road in silence. He watches her out of the corner of his eye.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You're not bawling, are you? She takes a breath, gathering herself.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Trying to figure out how to ask you about pay. He wasn't expecting this.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm assuming I'm working for room and board, but I was thinking an extra twenty five cents a week spending money as well. He snarls at this.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To make it feel official. His silence is a begrudging "yes". She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett walks into his shack, Maud follows behind. He lea Maud standing there by the door with her bag as he stokes the fire. She looks around the place. Everett stands, awkwardly shifting on his feet, after a moment, he turns and leaves the house again. More awkwardness as Maud looks for a place to lay her bag There is no room. Everything is caked in dirt and grime. Finally, Maud sits in a chair, her bag on her lap. She studies several old worn mugs that hang on nails along th wall. Mugs that are chipped and stained, but that had onc been quite pretty. Everett comes back in with a stack of wood in his arm.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: There you are, thought you left me. She giggles. He drops the pile of wood by the fire, and a chunk of wood lands on MaudвЂ™s foot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She tries to hide the pain.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So...what do you want me to do first?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I dunno. I guess - He looks around, not sure what to say. Their mutual discomfort thickens the air. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If I got to stand here and tell you everything, IвЂ™1ll just do it myself. He leaves again. Maud looks around the tiny home. ONE roo with a tiny staircase going to a loft upstairs. Nothing but a table, two chairs, an arm chair, a wood sto and some shelves. Some potatoes and a turnip, some carrot sit on the floor next to the stove. A bucket with water i it as well. Maud stands up. Where to begin? Finally, she unzips her little bag, and starts to unpack few of her things. She notices a horizontal wooden beam, and neatly lays her things on it, in a row: her brush, her mirror, a picture her mother, one of FLUFFY, her cat, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is outside, curious about Maud, as he discreetly peers in through the window. He watches as she hobbles ar collecting the dirty dishes. He can hear the sounds of her humming to herself. He turn up his nose at this cheeriness. As he pulls a trolly, Eve does a sharp whistle to the dogs. They follow him as he heads down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud has a pot of soup on the stove, and she has a portio of the house cleaned. But she has gotten distracted by EverettвЂ™s things, unab resist poking around. She sits in a rocking chair as she sifts through his old tin can filled with tattered photog and oddities: A photograph of a young boy, with a woman, looks like his mother. A tiny wooden incomplete chiseled wooden horse. The little tin toy sherrif's badge, we saw him fix. A little toy gun, made out of wood and nails. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maud studies them with interest. Then Everett walks in th 44 door, startling Maud.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What is going on here? Maud drops the can of photos.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Get outta my stuff! You think thatвЂ™s what I brought you here for? Maud gets on her hands and knees, picking up the photos.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look. You hardly lifted a finger since I left. RootinвЂ™ around in my gear. He sees a pot cooking on the stove.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I was taking a break. I made soup. He dips the ladle in, tastes the soup. He sneers and thro the ladle down aggressively. Maud jumps with fright.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What you put in that? I might look stupid, but IвЂ™m far from it. Look you havenвЂ™t even cleaned the table.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I was getting to that... Everett looks at her, it suddenly dawning on him.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You wanting money, and for what? You don't know a click about cleaning. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I just need to get the hang of it.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I don't want a lazy arse around here. Pack up AND GET. He swipes her little belongings off the shelf and onto th floor. Then he gets up and climbs the ladder to the loft. Maud canвЂ™t believe her ears. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 45 46 CONTINUED: (2) 36.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Where am I sвЂ™posed to go?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You shoulda thought about that when you were sitting around twiddling your thumbs.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I needed a day to find my feet, you never told me where anything was what you wanted me to do with your stuff, IвЂ™m just gettin' a lay of the land.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m not gonna look after ya!!! I wants someone who'll do the lookinвЂ™ after. Not some crippled up little thing looking to rob me. Now get out. He climbs up to the loft. Maud watches in disbelief, unsu of what to do.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Get OUT!!! Maud fights back the tears as she gathers her things and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud stands outside of EverettвЂ™s house. The wind blows wildly. Maud starts to walk towards the road, but she stops and l back to EverettвЂ™s house. She is completely lost as to w to go. Standing in the middle of nowhere, Maud looks as i she's about to cry. But instead... ...She turns her back to the wind and leans against it. I is so powerful that it almost holds her up. She outstretc her arms and lets the wind beat against her. This action starts to soothe her. She finally closes her eyes, a smile spreading across her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett stares out his window at Maud as the wind gives h a beating while she stands in the middle of the yard. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He blows out his lantern, and climbs into bed. 36A. 46  47 48 49 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next morning, Everett wakes up to sounds coming from downstairs. He climbs down from the loft and sees Maud scrubbing the floor. He stares at her in disbelief. She is sweating buckets, a she uses all her force to ring out what is left of her cl It is killing her hands, but she presses on. Meanwhile, she has made an attempt to set the table. His mug and his plate are neatly placed. Two slices of toast wait for him. Some freshly picked wildflowers are placed a bottle. Everett completely ignores her and climbs down the stairs He gathers his things to head out for work. He grabs the toast, slugs back the tea, and heads out the door, withou saying a word. She smiles. Then starts to clean the smoke stains from th walls. Her crippled hands makes scrubbing very difficult but she withstands the pain to get the job done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud digs a chicken out of the coop, but it breaks free. She chases it around the yard. She finally catches it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t blame you my son. IвЂ™d run too. She takes it over to the wood stump, it fights to break f but she holds on tightly.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: God bless you, poor soul. Maud sends the ax down on the chickenвЂ™s neck. Feathers blood fly about as Maud winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud has a stew cooking on the stove as she continues to clean, despite the pain it is causing her As she removes things off the shelf, she notices the once blue shelf is thick with dust. She looks at it thoughtful for a moment before she closes her eyes and BLOWS on it. Some of the dust blows away, but revealing more dust and grime. The blue is still buried. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: On her way to get the scrub brush, she notices an old can green paint. Maud eyes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud has just finished the last touches of paint on the s It is now a bright green. She smiles, pleased with hersel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett comes in late at night. Maud sits waiting nervous in the arm chair. Everett says nothing. He sits on a broken chair by the do and removes his boots. He sees the steamy pot of stew on the stove. He looks around, checking the place out, then looks at Maud.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s my chair. She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Let me get you a bowl aвЂ™ stew. She goes over to the stove and scoops up a hefty serving then places it at the table. Everett sits down and eats. He eyeballs her little things on the shelf, bothered by the presence of her belongings. Maud goes over to EverettвЂ™s boots and neatly places the side by side. She watches out of the corner of her eye as he eats.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: WhereвЂ™d you get the chicken.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Killed it. The scrawny one. Everett is surprised, and silently impressed.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So...am I able to stay then?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: We'll see if you can follow my rules. Maud watches him eat, half afraid to speak. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Where am I to sleep?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You clean upstairs?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Only one bed up there. IвЂ™m wondering where I should settle in. Everett gets up, scoops himself up another bowl of stew.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: No room for princesses here. When I was a youngster, sleeping in the orphanage, thereвЂ™d be seven or eight of us in the bed. Feet up my nose, elbows in my arse. YouвЂ™re too fancy to pile in up there, you can pack up your little knick-knacks and go on. Maud has no choice.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m only the size of a flea. SвЂ™pose I can fit somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett and Maud lay on either side of the mattress in th loft bedroom. It is awkward, and silent. Maud tries to keep her eyes closed, but she canвЂ™t sleep. She hears heavy sighs comi out of Everett lying next to her. Meanwhile, on Everett's side of the bed, he is forcing th sound of his breathing, feigning sleep, while he lies the completely awake, his wheels turning.

dialogues.speaker: TIME PASSAGE
dialogues.text: The moon slowly disappears, while the light begins to cha from black to orange. As the sun rises over the landscape Everett's little house stands alone against the colorful sky....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is trying to feed the dogs as they jump up on her (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 54 55 CONTINUED: 40. 54

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Off. Get. Brown. She shoves them off of her.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go on, Blackie. Out of my way. Everett is loading up wood in his truck. He looks at her suddenly resenting her presence.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Who said you could talk to them like that?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: They were gettinвЂ™ mud on me.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: They been here longer than you, and I tell you, they been a lot more useful.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m only tryinвЂ™ to feed them.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Shut your gob woman! IвЂ™11 tell you how it goes. ItвЂ™s me. ItвЂ™s them dogs. Them chickens. Then itвЂ™s you. He climbs in the truck and leaves. Maud watches resentful biting her tongue as Everett drives away. She continues t feed the dogs while they jump all over her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud sits on the bench outside the general store, eating can of sardines with her fingers, when Aunt Ida approache the store. When she sees Maud, she stiffens.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Hi there. I'm taking a break from work.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Nobody believes you are working for that man, he's practically a beggar. Everyone's talking he has you barred up in there as his love slave. It's disgusting. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maud bursts into a fit of laughter. She covers her mouth shyly, but can't stop laughing.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: (laughing) Everett with a love slave. Ida keeps walking into the store.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would it make it more proper if I married him? Then maybe they won't talk so much. Ida ignores this.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you like to visit me sometime? At my new house? Ida balks.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be caught dead. I wouldn't even drive by that house. Ida turns and walks into the store. Maud waits for a mome then gets up and makes her way down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud sits at her spot at the table, painting a picture. A little girl in a PINK DRESS at the centre.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is driving his truck, with a young, pleasant look man, FRANK (30) in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: We're dumping this stuff off, then you go on, don't go lingering around like a horsefly. I got work to do. Frank laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Gee, really? You're not going to invite me in for tea? But Everett is agitated. They pull into his driveway.  42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank is helping Everett unload some scrap metal from the back of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What are you gonna do with all this, Ev.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Sell it. Leave it here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Who'd buy that? Maud comes to the door, smiling. Frank is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Nice day. Frank takes Maud in, then smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Ahhh. Hello there. Everett got a woman. Everett, embarrassed, glares at Maud.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Go in the house, you. He looks back at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: She's working for me. I gotta have someone to mind the house while I'm away, otherwise they'll rob me blind.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (laughing) You've got a tiny little woman to guard your house? Couldn't you get a meaner dog? Or a gun? Frank lays down his end of the scrap metal.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to Maud) Wait, comeвЂ™ere. IвЂ™m Frank. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm the fisherman Everett tries to cheat every day.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: He wouldn't cheat you, he's a good man.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh, so you don't know Everett well I see. Frank smirks at Everett, who sneers back. Maud walks towa him, timidly smiling.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh hi. IвЂ™m Maud.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you. You're working here?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'm living here. Everett bristles.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: That's enough.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: So you've got a live in Maid, do ya? Frank looks at Everett, teasing. Everett reacts defensive

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I'm gone all day, every day. I'm a busy man. I deserves a clean house when I get home.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: (to Maud) Where do you fit in there? Maud is happy to be having pleasant conversation. Everett is staring in disbelief and outrage.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh, I'd fit anywhere, IвЂ™m sure. More room in there then you'd think. She smiles. Looks to Everett. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 58 59 CONTINUED: (2) 44. 58

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We find it cozy in there, don't we? Then out of nowhere, he raises his hand to Maud, and SLAP Maud in the face. Maud is taken aback. So is Frank. Even Everett is a little stunned by his actions. But he stiffe refusing to apologize.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Get in the house. A shocked Maud turns and runs inside. INTERCUT with:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud runs into the house, humiliated. OUTSIDE: Everett continues to rant to Frank.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I'm the boss of this house, and if she don't know it, she'll learn it. INSIDE: Maud looks - with all the chairs still outside, M has nowhere to sit, so she flops down on the floor in the corner, leaning into the wall. OUTSIDE: Frank continues to unload the truck

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Nobody in their right mind will put up with that for long.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah, well she ain't in her right mind, that's one thing I know. INSIDE: Maud sits there, holding back all her tears. Then she notices the can of GREEN PAINT again. She slides the cover off and dips her finger in the paint. Then she draw a little picture of a TREE on the wall. It comforts her Calms her. Moments later, Everett walks into the house. He sees her the floor. As she wipes her finger off in her apron, she glares at Everett.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope you learned your lesson. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 60 CONTINUED: 45. 59

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m learning something, for sure.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: SulkinвЂ™ in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Do you want me here or donвЂ™t you? Everett says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cuz IвЂ™1l go, IвЂ™1l1 walk out right now. Do you want me here or not? He refuses to answer.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If youвЂ™re just gonna kick me out one of these days anyway, say it and IвЂ™1l get. He stares at her angrily, but doesn't speak.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And If you're gonna keep on being that kind of boss... I'd like my pay please. He sneers at her, but she stands defiantly, her crooked h held out.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You haven't paid me yet, not once. After a moment, he reaches into his pocket and pulls out couple of quarters. He flicks them on the table and leave After the door shuts, Maud gets up off the floor She exhales, relieved, then takes a seat - in EVERETTвЂ™S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is in the midst of cleaning when there is an aggress knock on the door. She looks up, startled.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Open the damn door, I know you're in there. Maud freezes in her spot. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There's smoke coming from the chimney. I know you're home. Maud gently tip toes over to peer out the window. But jus as she does the woman moves towards the window, so Maud h the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman, SANDRA (40) a spunky, attractive woman, presse her face to the window.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You can't hide in there forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud gently crawls over towards the door, and peaks throu the crack between the door and the floor.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I suppose you think I'm a dumb woman and I wouldn't notice. You are wrong. All she can see are the woman's shoes. Beautiful, burgund leather shoes with a tiny bow on them. Maud studies the detail of the shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra is getting agitated. She lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You don't know who you're dealing with. I invented the word stubborn. She sits there, in silence for a moment. Then...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They're some snazzy shoes. Sandra stops inhaling the cigarette. Is she hearing thing

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Hello? Sandra looks around. She can hear someone shuffling aroun inside. Maud creaks open the door (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I said you're wearing snazzy shoes. They comfy? Sandra looks at Maud in disbelief. Who is this creature?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Ah, they're not bad. Sorry, are you the fish peddler's wife?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Gonna ask you the same thing. You're so mad, I figured you had to be married to him.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: He short changed me one time too many. Is he around?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: The fish peddler. Maud chuckles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: "Fish peddler". I usually calls him the old crab. (then serious) But not to his face. Maud, realizing the woman has business on her mind.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everett's out on the rounds.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Well...I paid him for fish and he never delivered. Maud hides her embarrassment and tries to cover for Evere

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: He's doing so much, sometimes he forgets.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I paid him, plus a handsome tip. Now, I'm here from New York for the whole summer, I can give him my business or not. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 Maud smiles. 63

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: From New York the city. That must be different.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I'm having a dinner party tonight, I need three fish. Maud is determined to give Everett the benefit of the dou

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You sure he never dropped the fish off? Maybe your dog ran off with it -

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I don't have a dog -

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: - Or your cat. Cats love a fish. Sandra gets firm with Maud.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: No cat. Sandra tries to take a bold step inside. Maud stands her guard, all while smiling up at Sandra politely.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'll tell him you came by. But Sandra is distracted when she sees the paintings on t walls. She studies them: A happy looking Chicken, and several bright flowers.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll tell Everett to square up with you when he gets home. Sandra looks at Maud with a new interest.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I'd appreciate that. Did you paint that happy little chicken?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 64 CONTINUED: (3) 49. 63

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (looking at the chicken) That's Ches. He was a chicken out in the yard. I killed him. For supper. I wanted to remember his happier days. Sandra smiles, charmed.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'm Maud. Sandra looks at Maud curiously.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you Maud. I'm Sandra. They smile at each other, and Maud closes the door. Maud goes back to the table by the window, and finds a scrap o card stock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is standing fairly close to Everett as she attempts serve up his supper. He watches her, but she's clumsy and slow. Finally he grabs the serving spoon out of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Gimme some elbow room woman. Maud backs off. Everett scoops up his own plate of food.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Whole goddamned place is taken over Feel like squirrels moved in. Who told you to put them rat tracks on my walls?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Just doing what you asked.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yes, I told you to paint fairies all over my house. Maud giggles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That's a bird. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 CONTINUED: 50. 64

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You told me to make the place look alright. I think it looks alright. You? He looks around. Then begrudgingly gives in.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Leave that wall behind the stove alone. That's MY wall. Maud sits down at the table with him as he eats. She wait a moment before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Thinking about my brother Charles. Everett doesn't look up.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He used to run one a them jazz clubs for awhile. Always people on his back for money he owed them. He always said people were trying to rob him out, but he couldn't prove it. Must be tough running a business.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I owes nobody.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Apparently Charles never owed anyone, but he never had proof. It was hard to keep track of it all.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Only if you're stupid.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Maybe. And you're not. You're a really smart man. Too smart probably. You can keep track of all this in your head but most people can't. Everett likes the sound of this, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You got to dumb it down.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What's that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 64 65 CONTINUED: (2) 51. 64

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Well. I guess you gotta think like a dumb person, and write it all down. I can help you, you want. Maud holds up one of her little cards. She has made crook lines on it, a place for the name/amount in/amount out.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Never mind who you owe money to. Who owes you money? Everett thinks, skeptically. Then...

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: The Donovan's owes me for two fish. He thinks some more. CanвЂ™t think of anyone else. Maud w the name down on the card, and the amount owed.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: And can you think of anyone you owes fish to? Everett slinks back in his chair

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: SвЂ™pose I owes LinehanвЂ™s, I owes them two fish. Maud writes this on a new card. When she is finished, she turns the card over, revealing simple, scenic painting on each card. Flowers, Trees, bir He looks at the paintings.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh, I thought it'd make the cards a little friendlier looking. She smiles at him. He shakes his head at her, but lets it go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud and Everett are tucked in their bed. Maud's eyes are closed, while Everett is wide awake. He stares at Maud fo a bit. Then gathers the courage to approach her, albeit a little ungracefully. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He gently touches Maud's hair. Then he rolls over and lie on top of her, and fumbles around, trying to lift up her nightdress. Maud looks at Everett strangely. 65

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Are we gonna get married? Everett looks at her, almost surprised to hear her speak

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Foolish. Money racket, that is. Maud giggles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Only if you invite people, and have a dance and stuff. Give everyone supper.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It all costs money, even the license to do it costs money. WonвЂ™t catch me at it. Maud stares at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Hmmmm . Everett snorts.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charles had a wedding. His wife wanted a fancy wedding, so he had to scrounge up every cent he had. I said, if I ever get married, I won't be inviting anyone. I'd just do it for cheap, at the town hall. Everett yanks the blanket up over his shoulder. Maud keep talking.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Why are you yakking about him, I don't care about him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Well. If you plan on rolling over to my side of the bed, I think we better get married. I got in that sort of trouble once before, I don't think I should be at it again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What trouble? Maud hesitates, then...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh. You know. Wasn't married, had a baby, shamed my family. Everett looks at her, in disbelief. She looks at him, hop he'll understand.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Baby died. Never even saw her Charles and Aunt Ida buried her while I was sleeping. Everett stares at Maud for a moment, a little dumbfounded Then he turns over on his back again, and closes his eyes go to sleep. After a moment, Maud does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud walks with Everett who pushes his wheel barrow. She has a scarf tied around her head, as she walks proudly do the road. She has a hard time keeping up to him, but does her best.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You're gonna have to wait up.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You're gonna have to speed up. Or I'll put you in the wheelbarrow. People stare at the two of them strangely. EXT. SANDRAвЂ™S SUMMER HOME - DAY 67 Maud hangs back on the step as Everett knocks on Sandra's door. After a moment, Sandra answers it. She's a complete disas covered in flour, and holding a wooden spoon in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Well, look who it is. You've caught me at my most domestic. I'm making a thing called "chocolate chipped cookies". Everett's not in the mood for small talk. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 67 CONTINUED: 54. 67

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Here, look. He hands her three fish.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The three fish you wanted. I only owed you for two fish. Now you owes me for one. Sandra looks at him strangely.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We figured it out on the card, look. Now you owes me back for one fish. Maud steps up.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: WeвЂ™re rendering accounts, so there wonвЂ™t be a mix up.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I never told you to speak. Maud puts her head down. Sandra looks at the card, skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: How do I know this is right?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Cuz I said it was. Maud looks up again.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Maybe we should just start clean from now on weвЂ™1ll keep track. Everett shoots her another look.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I said shut UP. Maud looks down again. Sandra looks at Everett, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Give me a minute. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then she takes the card and goes back in the house. Maud picks a speck of paint off of her hands as Everett r Everett glares at Maud who waits on the lower step, eyes the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m the boss, you does what I say. IвЂ™m the boss, donвЂ™t forget it. Who brings in the money?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You do.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: That's right. Don't forget it. INT. SANDRAвЂ™S SUMMER HOME - DAY 68 As Sandra goes to get her purse, she tosses the card down the table, finally noticing the beautiful little painting the back - A winter wonderland scene. EXT. SANDRAвЂ™S SUMMER HOME - DAY 69 Sandra comes out again, with money and the card in hand.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
