dialogues.text: I'll pay you. If you make me some more of these cards. She looks at Maud, who looks back, stunned.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Christmas cards. More like this. Everett doesn't know what to think. Maud looks to him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I dunno. It's up to the boss. I does what he says. Everett is dumbfounded for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Alright. Throw in an extra five cents.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Fine. How about ten cents a card. Wow. Even better than he intended. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett grabs the money from Sandra, who ignores him, but smiles at Maud.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I look forward to them very much. She and Maud smile at each other warmly. Everett clocks this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk down the road, Maud struggles to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You're good Ev. I gotta say, I never woulda thought to ask for that money. You really know what you're doing. Everett is somewhat pleased as well, as he walks ahead of her.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Get in second gear woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud sits at the little table in the corner by the window she paints an apple tree on a little card. A bright beam sunlight shines in on her. She looks out the window and sees a group of children wal by - one little girl in a pink dress among them. She stud her closely....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More of Everett's house has been painted - a butterfly on the door, flowers around the windows. Maud is now paintin the stairs on the way up to the loft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is with Frank. He has found some old cans of paint and he's handing them off to Maud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud sits at the table with her paints. She dips a paintb into a little container of paint. She scrapes it against paint splattered sardine can. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks at herself in the mirror for a moment. It's difficult for her. But she smiles a little, and takes her paint brushes and paints a little tiny flower on the fram Then she turns back to a large painting on a wooden board that is half-way finished. She makes her large, unrefined paint strokes. An outdoor scene. A tire swing now hangs from a tree. A little girl in a pink dress. Maud looks out the window, and sees Everett chopping wood He effortlessly splits each wood chuck in two with one fe swoop. He is concentrated, and relentless. Maud stops her painting for a moment and watches him admiringly. A sweet, shy smiles comes across her face. She turns her attention back to the painting, and starts paint Everett, in his plaid shirt, hard at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is collecting money from Mr. McDougal.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Here's a few more to sell. The storekeeper looks at the cards skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: MR. MCDOUGAL
dialogues.text: I don't know why people are paying money for these. My five year old can do better. Everett looks out the window of the store, where Maud is waiting outside. Then, he leans into the storekeeper angrily.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're talking about. How foolish are you. These are good drawings, and that's why people are paying good money for it. You, my son, are an idiot. Everett stomps off, outside the store to join Maud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud and Everett walk across the wide open field, two col specks among the dull yellow grass. 74 75 76  77

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud and Everett are in the house, Everett is poking the wood stove as Maud sits at the table, painting. Everett leans over and sneaks a peak at what she's doing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 57A.
dialogues.text: 77  77 CONTINUED: 58. It's one of Three Black Cats.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You like em? He looks away.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: My paintings.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to know if they're good or not. That's women's stuff. But he stops and looks at them. Takes them all in. Then h notices down at the bottom, where her name is signed, it says... Maud LEWIS.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's that? I know what that says that's my name there. But you're a Dowley. Maud bites her lip.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Well. Yeeeeah. But I figured, where we're partners, and the painting is half yours. So... part of your name should be on it too. Right? He looks around the house. Nothing's been done. It's a bi of a mess.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You gonna get at some of the housework now, or what?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I've got to finish a few more of these first.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Lord, woman, you can't neglect the chores. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I know, but there are only so many hours in the day.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Might as well start doing it all myself. He grabs the apron. Maud smiles to herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud and Everett are sitting down to a quiet supper when there is a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Whoever it is, tell 'em to vamoose. Maud gets up to open it. It's Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: It's cold out here, may I come in? Maud looks back to Everett. Everett gives a sharp point towards the road - in other words "get". Maud looks back Sandra and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Um, weвЂ™re just gettinвЂ™ supper ready. But Sandra isnвЂ™t deterred, taking in Maud and her surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Smells like it. I won't stay long. Sandra smiles at Maud, as she nudges her way in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett looks up from the table, in disbelief. Maud stand nervously between the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: He likes it quiet when he eats -

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I didn't think he could hear.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I hear fine. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett glares at her as she plunks herself down on a cha She ignores Everett and turns to Maud excitedly. SANDRA (CONTвЂ™D) Show me one of your larger paintings.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t do larger paintings, just the cards.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Oh, you must. IвЂ™m willing to pay your price. Maud just shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yes she does. Everett reaches down under the couch, and pulls out the painting of the little girl and the tire swing. Maud look at him, shaking her head "no". But he grins.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Some fine gobs of paint flicked on this board. Right up your alley -

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m not even finished that.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Let me see it. Sandra studies it.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Beautiful. Maud shrugs, smiling shyly.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This tree has red leaves, and this one has green. What season is it? Maud shrugs again.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh, guess itвЂ™s everything thatвЂ™s pretty about all seasons.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: How much? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™s your price.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Nah, not for sale, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Five dollars.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No. IвЂ™m not selling it.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Already sold. Everett takes the painting and hands it to Sandra. Maud throws Everett a look.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: But, IвЂ™m not finished it. He sees something in her eyes. A pleading look. Sandra doesn't notice, she's absorbed with the painting. He grab the painting from Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Only joshing you. It's not for sale. Sandra looks back at Maud, realizing she's not getting he to budge.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You know what would be even better? If I commissioned you to paint something for me. She takes out five dollars and goes to give it to Maud. Maud refers it to Everett. Sandra begrudgingly gives it t Everett.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Paint me anything. On a board like this, just whatever you want. You can send it to me in New York. Show me how you see the world. Maud smiles shyly.  80 81 62.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud looks at the framed scenery outside her window. It's cold, dreary, bleak day. Rain is pelting down hard. EVERE is outside, carting loads of wood out of the shed. Maud watches through the window as Everett heads towards her w the wheel barrow. His face stern. Serious, as he shields himself from the pelting rain. She can hear him muttering curses. Vulnerable, but hard. She smiles to herself. She looks back down at the painting. It is of Everett enjoying his work on a sunny day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud and Everett are in bed. It is almost completely dark and Maud is nearly asleep. Everett reaches under the blanket and pokes at Maud.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You awake? Maud can barely open her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Yeah. He pokes at her some more. Then moves a little closer to her and starts to rub up against her. She doesnвЂ™t respo but she fully wakes up. Everett gropes at her more aggressively. She turns to him

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know, I think we can afford that marriage license.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Foolish.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Well, we can. Everett rolls over and away from her She looks at him, a little beam of moonlight shines acros his face. His eyes glisten as he stares at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Everyone wants wants wants. If I want something, I gotta fork out. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 80 81  81 CONTINUED: 63. Maud listens. 81

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stay on your side of the bed, you wonвЂ™t catch me over there again. Maud stares at the ceiling, so does Everett.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I want to, I just think we should get married first.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Never mind your bribing. Leave me alone. He turns his back to her.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sorry. IвЂ™m not bribing. I just... She moves over and puts her arms around him. She snuggles into his back. Everett looks at her, his face softening. He moves closer to her and fumbles around under the blank Maud lays still as the dark room is filled with the sound of EverettвЂ™s awkward grunts. Maud hangs onto Everett, appreciating the closeness. She hugs tightly into him. But it lasts only momentarily. Within moments, he is fini and he rolls off of her. She smiles at him. He suddenly seems shy and nervous.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was nice. Everett says nothing. He seems pained. Awkward. She reach over and touches him, but he recoils.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Don't. He is suddenly really uncomfortable with the closeness.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't think you're worming your way into my life, like this, cuz you're not. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you stop doing your job, you are out on your duff in a flash, you understand? And if you think IвЂ™m going marrying you so I can do that you're sick in the head. Rather do it to a knot in a tree. Maud glares at him, furiously, then climbs out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where you goinвЂ™ now? Maud says nothing, but disappears down the ladder After a moment, he hears the sound of the door slam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud sits outside and smokes a cigarette while sitting in between the two dogs, Blackie and Brownie. She looks at the dog who stares at the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is downstairs, watching Maud through the window. can see that she is talking to the dogs, and she doesn't look too happy. But he stubbornly heads back upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett comes outside with two cups of tea. He sees Maud, curled up next to the two dogs where she spent the night. She hears the door slam closed and sits up. Everett approaches her, holding out the cup of tea. She wonвЂ™t take it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: SвЂ™pose youвЂ™1l throw that in my face next.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I might. She refuses the tea. After a moment, he tosses the tea ac the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If you don't know what I'm like by now, you're stunned-er than you look (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She looks down at her feet.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: We live together in this house, we might as well get married.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Just cuz I don't have women beating down my door, doesn't mean I got to marry up with the first one who'll have me.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Well. Why not? We've been living in this house together now for almost a year. Silence. Everett is biting the side of his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It'd be nice to be like normal people, wouldn't it? That's what normal people do, they get married.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You're not a normal woman.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You need me. He looks away.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I don't need anybody. Never did.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Foolish. Everybody needs somebody. That's life. And you don't need many people. But you need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is wearing her best dress, her lovely broach pinned her chest, and a flower in her hair. She stands, nervousl waiting for...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is putting on a tattered suit that has been clean and pressed. He stands in the mirror, straightening himse out. Smoothing down his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud stands against the wall, observing as a line of youn boys pass by her. She smiles, tickled by their cute faces Mr. Hill is at the end of the line. Then, Everett comes out, shiny clean.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You look nice.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Let's go. As they walk down the hall, Mr. Hill smiles at Maud.

dialogues.speaker: MR. HILL
dialogues.text: Big day for you two. Congratulations. She smiles, and tucks her chin into her sweater. She's nervous. Happy. Because...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EVERETT and MAUD come out of the church having just gotte married. Maud is holding a bouquet of flowers. Frank is there with his wife. Frank smiles at Maud.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: I don't know if I should offer congratulations or condolences, Maud, but give me a hug. He hugs her. Then offers his hand to Everett.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You be nice.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah yeah. But Everett shakes his hand. Maud links her arm into EverettвЂ™s as they walk down the step. At first he tense up, but then he relaxes. A smile almost appears on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud, still in her modest wedding dress, sits in the wheelbarrow, proud as a princess, as Everett pushes her through an open field filled with yellow daisies.  90 91 92 67.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of Maud and Everett having sex in the loft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud looks at him with love as they have sex. It is awkwa but gentle. He rolls over when they are done. EVERETT (CONTвЂ™D) DonвЂ™t go thinking that everythingвЂ™s all mushy now. IвЂ™m still contrary.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Every time I says something cross you canвЂ™t run off to the shed and bitch to the dogs. Maud smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: We're like a good pair of socks. He gives her a sarcastic look

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Oh yes. One shriveled up sock, all clingy, the other one long, too thin, full a holes - She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Better than only one sock.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe. She gently lays her head on his arm, wanting the intimacy but not wanting to scare him off. She smiles. Happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun begins to set into the landscape, as a flock of b head off in a hurry across the darkening sky. The tinny sound of music blares from the minuscule house... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: A 1950's car cruises along the road, passing by the Lewis home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An older Maud is sitting down at the table, her increasin feeble hands hold a copy of the Star Weekly magazine, whi she reads from. Everett is now washing the dishes, wearin the apron that Maud sometimes wears. A tiny transistor radio plays music in the background.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: ".,.,Her paintings can be found on display at her home in Marshalltown Nova Scotia, where she lives with her husband, Everett Lewis", see they do mention you "a local fish peddler."

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: They said my name? Let me see? She holds out the paper as his eyes study the words, look for a word he recognizes. He spots it and points to it.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's it there. She smiles proudly as she places the paper down. He wipes his hands dry, and starts to slice and butter a few piece of bread.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Bet we'll sell more paintings now.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Next you'll be wanting us to get electricity or something.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Foolish.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: We'll have to buy a television.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What do we want a television for? I got that radio. Might need some new batteries soon. He brings over a plate of sliced bread. They both eat a piece. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93 94 95 CONTINUED: 69. 93

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We can afford batteries. Quiet moment as they eat their bread. She looks back at t article.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wonder who is out there reading this right now?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Nobody. You know what people are doing with this article? They're lighting their wood-stoves with it. So don't go getting too big for your britches. You're still my employee. Maud laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'm not your employee. I'm your wife.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well, I'm still the main earner.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Of course. I'm only practicing up. If people pays money for it, that's your doin', not mine. He nods, satisfied with this "agreement".

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: As long as you don't start getting fancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud's hands are clearly worsening as she carries an old painted board with the words "Paintings for Sale". She wa out towards the road. Then, she leans the board against a old rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett walks home from a day's work, looking tired and w out. As he nears his own house, he slows down as he passe by the sign.  70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks into his driveway, and looks at Maud, who is sta next to Sandra, and several other curious visitors. Maud has many paintings leaning up against the house. A few interested people have pulled off on the side of the road and are now milling about the house, admiring Maud and he work. Everett looks on nervously. When Maud sees him, she smile He smiles back. Awkward, but slightly excited. As Sandra is distracted with talking to potential customers, Everet walks over to Maud.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: How much money we get today?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I think around eighteen dollars. Maybe more. Everett looks pleased by this.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Give it, I'll put it somewhere safe. Maud takes the money out of her apron pocket and hands it Everett. He looks at Sandra, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: She still bugs you.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I don't trust her.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: She's my friend.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Pff! Everett goes back to chopping his wood. Sandra rejoins Maud.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Shall we have a cup of tea?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Why don't we go for a walk. Give Everett some peace. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: As they walk away, Everett doesn't notice. He keeps chopp his wood, his back to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud and Sandra are strolling along a wide open field.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: If he made you some stretched canvases, you'd get a lot more money for those paintings.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I wouldn't ask him. Sandra helps Maud along. Maud's much more feeble than San and the walk is a little difficult for her

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: So what's it like being married to such an ass? (off Maud's look) Sorry. "Grump".

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Never been married to anyone else, so what would I compare it to? Sandra looks at her for a beat before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I've been dying to ask you for years. Do you ever feel you are in love? Maud smiles shyly.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You do? You mean you think you love Everett? Actual love? Maud shrugs, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And is he in love with you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: This is foolish talk. How would I know that? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97 98 CONTINUED: 72. 97

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Well...does he smile at you when you walk into the room, does he do little nice things to show you he cares? Does he pay you compliments. Maud and Sandra sit on the grass, and Maud slips off her shoes, and gives this some thought.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: If that's what it means, then no, I wouldn't say Everett loves much. Maud SCRUNCHES her feet in the grass. Sandra does the sam

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Guess your husband must be nice to you.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: God, no. I didn't marry for love, I married for...I don't know. Money? To make my parents happy? Boredom? Stupid really. Marriage should be preserved for great love.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Nah, we need to be happy with what we got. They sit side by side, it's peaceful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is still splitting wood when he looks over and se his dog Brownie, lying on her side, looking ill. He goes over to her.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Brownie, get up. What's going on? He whistles sharply. The dog doesn't respond. He bends down toward the dog, suddenly worried.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Brown? No movement. Very laboured breathing from the dog. The other dog, Blackie, stands beside Everett, looking on. Everett looks over to where Maud was. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 98 99 100 CONTINUED: 73. 98

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Miss. Miss! But she's not there.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Something's wrong with Brownie! Miss. Everett is becoming extremely upset. He looks back at the dog.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't leave me Brown. He heads towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he opens the door to the house, he is surprised to discover Maud's chair empty.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Maud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up the road. No Maudie. Down the road. No Maudie

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: God Damnit. Everett stands still, the world suddenly spinning. He loo around frantically. Then Everett goes back to the dog. The dog is dead. He's unsure of how to deal with his emotions.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Woman! Woman!!! Then he sees Maud walking towards the house in the distan His frantic panic turns to anger as he steadies his breat watching her as she hurries towards him. As she gets closer:

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where the hell where you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Went for a walk with Sandra. What's wrong? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 101 CONTINUED: 74. 100

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Brown's dead.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No. She hurries over and looks at Brownie.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: But never you mind, go off on your fancy prance around town with the priss bag.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Want me to help you bury her?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett and Maud sit on the ground next to Brownie's body just the two of them. Everett looks pained, but he sucks on his teeth and pulls himself up off the ground. He scratches Blackie on the ea Everett gets up and gets the shovel. Maud walks over and takes the collar off of the dead dog. She looks back at Everett.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Poor old girl.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yeah yeah yeah, she had a good life. Blackie's the poor one now. She reaches out for Everett's arm, but he brushes it off. She gets up, giving him the space.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'll go make sure the kettle's on. She walks back to the house, feeling uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I wasn't here. When you needed me.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I didn't need you. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beautiful vista of the house sitting alone against a cr morning sky as the vista is covered in a blanket of brigh white snow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is outside of her house, placing her paintings as a pulls up. Maud is surprised to see who's driving - it's h brother CHARLES. He looks older, and more tired. When he sees Maud he forces a big smile.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Charles?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Sister. He comes over and gives Maud a hug. It's polite, but awkw

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What are you doing here.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I read about you, had to come see for myself. An artist.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Foolish. I painted when we were kids, you never called me an artist then. No different now. Charles studies the house, trying to be polite.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I get you some tea?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: No, thank you for asking. Charles walks around.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where's your man?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Out on his rounds. Should be back soon, if you want to meet him. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Don't have a lot of time. Wanted to come by and maybe get one of your paintings. Maud smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Pick whatever one you want.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: That's kind of you. Then...

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Big ones are five dollars. Charles is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Aunt Ida said he is a miser. That you don't see a nickel of money from these paintings. Charles bites his lip, changing tactics.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What's he doing with your money, Maud? Maud doesn't know how to answer.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Saving it, I s'pose.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Why isn't he building onto the house? Getting the place wired?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Don't s'pose we need it. That's his choice to make.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: You're capable of making decisions aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You never thought so. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: When I read about you in the paper, I thought to myself, "that girl went out and got a life for herself after all." But here you are. Still being ruled by someone else. Maud can't argue with this. Charles walks around, staring at the paintings politely.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need someone to give you advice on how to handle your money. Someone a little more savvy than him. Someone who can find the proper investments.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Like you?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I know money.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You had to sell momma's house to pay off your debts. So I bet you do know money. And how slippery it is. Charles bristles, then glances up the road and sees Evere heading towards the house on his bicycle. Everett pulls up on his bike. Hops off, sizing up Charles but saying nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know my brother Charles.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Yup. Charles shifts uncomfortably. As he looks back to the paintings:

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You gonna buy one or what?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: Maybe another time. Charles nods a polite "goodbye" to Everett, then gets int his car. Everett waits for the car to pull out then, then goes straight to his shed and gets at his work (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maud watches Charles' car pull away. Then, she glances ba at Everett feeling conflicted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is buzzing with flies. Maud sits at her table, even more stooped and her hands m gnarled. She swats away the flies. Coughs periodically. A nagging, recurring tickle. Everett is peeling carrots.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: We need to get a screen door put up.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Where is the money coming from? I'm working fourteen hours a day just to keep you going with your hobby over there in the corner.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I bring in money with the paintings -

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You bring in a few pennies but you don't do a lick of work, I got to do everything. Everett puts a pot of water on the stove. He puts the car in the pot. Silence for a moment. Maud senses something i wrong. He pulls potatoes out of a bag, and starts peeling them. Maud looks at him, with his back to her. A quiet unease between them. Maud goes back to painting at her spot in t table. Swatting away the flies. She COUGHS again.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Think you can manage to keep that fire going? I like to have a cup a tea when I get home.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Gets hot in here in the day.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well open the door.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Then we get more flies. The screendoor -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: hut up about the screendoor. n Maud sees a letter on the table, and quickly hides it. Bu he sees this, and goes to grab it.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: oO h, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Give it to me. He grabs it, and looks at it. The envelope has the U.S. Presidential seal on it.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Vice-President Nixon.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What does he want?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh nothing. Paintings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett sneers up his lip. Maud catches this, and immedia downplays it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I'm telling him, I don't care how fancy he is, if he sends the money like every body else, I'll send him a painting. She looks to him, hoping this pleased him. But Everett le the house, without saying a word. Maud sits at her table, watching out the window as Everet heads up the road. Maud's eyes are filled with worry and uncertainty. After he is out of sight, she turns back to her painting. She coughs again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett walks away, a nervous, insecure man. He starts hi way up the road, then stops. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: God dammit. He turns back towards the shed and gets his wheelbarrow - he'd forgotten it. Then he heads down the road again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road outside Everett's house is now painted, and a po office box is placed on the side of the road as well. The little house is looking more shabby, with paint fading an peeling a little....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a cold, grey day outside. The wind is blowing. Ever looks well shaven. Tidy and clean. But he is on his knees, diggin up potatoes. He does it wi ease. But he seems aggravated. Self-conscious. He shakes his head and starts mumbling to himself.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Don't know what's so interesting about pulling potatoes out of the ground. WE realize he's talking to a film crew. They are set up behind him. Everett puts the potatoes ina bucket. He picks up the bucket and walks towards the hous The camera crew scurries to follow him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett walks around the front of the house, where there a CBC van parked, and several other crew members. Maud is standing up talking to the two filmmakers. As the camera person repositions the camera, Maud looks up at Everett a smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: There you are. Everett wipes the dirt off his knees as he looks at the c skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are interviewing Maud. Everett sits in the backgroun trying desperately to smile politely and naturally. Maud being interviewed by a young man named STEVEN. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Yeah. IвЂ™m working on another one of Oxen, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You like Oxen, why is that?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Dunno. TheyвЂ™re strong, but helpless.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: You always paint outdoor scenes?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Always.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN
dialogues.text: Why is that? Maud shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: He works outdoors a lot. People like pictures of outdoors. No big reason I guess. Maud laughs uncomfortably. She looks over at Everett, see he's also uncomfortable. She motions for him to move clos He does so, awkwardly, trying to force a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud and Everett now side by side, being interviewed outs their house, showing the paintings she has displayed for sale.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: This one is of seagulls. There's flowers painted on the door, here. Maud refers to Everett.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He thinks I'm foolish for painting on the walls. (looking at Everett) Don't you? He looks at the camera, trying to force a smile.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It's-it's not you. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The people who comes around are the- the-the foolish ones. Maud tries to cover up with a chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: One chap come up, wanted to buy the bird on the door, I said lord man you can't buy our door Maud smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: He got me to whip him up another bird on a board.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: The man wanted to fork over his money, I wasn't about to say no.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Everett's good at selling. We each does our thing, and it all works out pretty good. I paint most of the time, he does everything else. Maud smiles at Everett. He is very uncomfortable, but struggles to keep it hidden.

dialogues.speaker: STEVEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Everett you must feel very lucky to have Maud as your wife. The camera goes in closer on Everett's face, revealing hi nervousness, his insecurity. He swallows, then clears thi throat, trying to find something clever to say.... The pressure is mounting.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: . Yes. Steve waits for him to say something else.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: We're lucky to have each other. His stiff smile twitches in the uncomfortable moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra and a FEW FRIENDS mingle with drinks, as Sandra sh everyone, while standing in front of the TV. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Here she is, look.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: She's a sweet talented lady. Why does she stay with that man? Sandra watches with delight, as her friends gather around

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ida is propped up on the couch, looking sickly and exhaus but awake enough to watch Maud and Everett on TV.

dialogues.speaker: TV SHOW HOST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: - Her paintings have even been sold to Vice-President Nixon. This happy couple who only live with the bare necessities of life, and yet somehow they flourish... Ida stares at the image ON THE TELEVISION: Maud and Evere walking around their yard, talking. ON IDA'S FACE, filled with regret and sadness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud's brother Charles, worn out and tired, is sitting on bar stool, drinking a scotch, as a band sets up in the background. He is watching Maud on the little TV playing behind the bar, a sad look on his face.

dialogues.speaker: TV SHOW HOST, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who would have thought that this little arthritic woman, living on the fringe of society, would have such incredible and far-reaching success. You can find Maud Lewis still selling her paintings from the front step of her little house in Marshalltown, Nova Scotia...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is across the road from his house, getting the ma out of his mail box. A STACK of envelopes. He stands there, ripping open the letters, taking the mon from them and shoving them in his shirt pocket, then ripp the letters up into bits. Then, he hops on his bike and rides away... 1414 112 113 114

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is riding his bike as he pulls up to the store, looking more slouched and self-conscious than ever. A few PEOPLE trickle out of the store, staring at him wit more interest. He keeps his eyes to the ground, ignoring the stares. He mutters to himself. But then Everett notices Ida, who is in a wheelchair, bei helped into a car. She looks deathly ill, but when she se Everett, she props herself up anyway, just to glare at hi

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I saw you on the news. You lucked into it with her, didn't you? She's all smiles, and you nothing but grumbles.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: PfTff. He starts to ride off, but she calls out.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Wait. I want you to tell her to come see me. Please. He rides down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Everett pulls up to his house, he sees a LINEUP of car outside his home. Crowds of people admire the house, and Maud's paintings. He pushes through the people.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Watch it. Move. Move. He bumbles through them, flustered, and heads into the ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is sitting at the table, across from Everett.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: How sick was she?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Never mind how sick she was. I asked if I came across nasty on the TV. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ee eK *

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No Everett.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Well why is everyone giving me queer looks. I'm starting to feel like I can't show my face without people talking.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Never mind what anyone is saying.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Easy for you to say. Everyone thinks you're sweet and so good at your painting, they don't know what you're like to live with. Maud gets up from the table, ignoring his jibes.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I got to go see Aunt Ida. Maud grabs her jacket.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Because what if she dies and I never went to say goodbye. She hurries to the door.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: What if I dies and you're not here? You're always going off here, going off there. Starting to get fed up. Maud is about to walk out the door.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I said no. You can't go. She turns back to Everett.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I have to. She grabs a little painting and hurries out the door. Everett stares out the window, watching as she walks away His breathing heavy. Fuming. He paces the tiny floor spac (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then brushes his hand across Maud's table, filled with he paint supplies, scattering everything across the floor He goes back to the window and watches her again as she's walking off in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is walking out the long, empty paved road, a little painting tucked under her arm. A tiny speck in a vast emp space. Nothing between her and their little house, behind her in the distance. She hurries, as fast as her little crooked legs can move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud walks into the front hallway. The nurse sees Maud an smiles.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: SheвЂ™s awake in her room, go on up. Maud goes in. INT. IDAвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM -- CONTINUOUS Maud walks into IdaвЂ™s room, clutching her painting. Ida looks up, is clearly ill. She sees Maud and smiles feebly Maud hands her a painting.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like painting flowers. Here.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Thank you. Ida takes the painting, and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You don't need to stay mad at me forever. Ida is about to fight back, but then resigns from it.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I watched you on the TV and it dawned on me. You are the only one in our family who ended up happy. I thought it was impossible for you to have a good life. Maud sits on the side of Ida's bed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don't want to die full of regrets.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You're not gonna die -- Maud takes Ida's hand.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I regret not letting you see her, at least. Your baby.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You did it to protect me. She was dead and deformed, it would have be too much -- Ida hoists herself up a bit.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Maudie. She wasn't deformed. This is startling to Maud.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What do you mean? Why'd she die? Ida looks at her for a moment. Then...

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: She didn't.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: Charles sold her. Maud stumbles backwards.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: He sold her. For money. Finally...

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: He sold her to a good home. Older people. The man was a minister. Maud stares off, in complete shock.. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We didn't think you would be able to take care of a child. Maud recoils. She stands up, not sure what to do next.

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Charles and I decided -- Ida reaches out to Maud's arm.

dialogues.speaker: IDA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was told she's been well loved. Maud paces a little, trying to process this.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: And is she normal? Was she a normal baby, or was she crooked, or what?

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: She was fine. Maud gathers herself.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Have your soup, Ida. I gotta go. She leaves the painting on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: IDA
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Maud... Maud hurries out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is now taking all of Maud's painting supplies and throwing them into an wooden crate. Sardine cans, paint brushes, cans of paint, old boards, all aggressively bein chucked into the box. He knocks over the table, dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud has left Ida's house, and she wanders up the road, l in her confusion. Looking around, at people's faces, at houses. Who could she be? Where is she? It begins to rain. Maud hugs her coat tightly into her an hurries down the road.  123 89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Maud comes home, she is still in a daze. She hardly notices Everett, who is sitting in her chair, with a scow on his face.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I'm sick of you.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Ev, don't, not now.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I never asked for this. Go out in the morning, people, come home for lunch, people, back at the end of the day, more people. Didn't like 'em before, don't like em now. I never wanted my face on the TV for the whole world to laugh at.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Everett. Ida told me -

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: If I'm not good enough for you, you want to find something better then what I can give you, go. Go find it. But Maud is desperate to talk to him - her husband. She persists.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Listen to me Everett. All these years, I've figured I was half a woman cuz I gave birth to some little gnarled up creature that couldn't live. It wasn't even true. She bites her lip.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The baby lived. My brother - he sold her. Everett stares at her for a moment, then suddenly he poun his fist down on the table.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Give up talking about that God damned baby. The brother, the baby. Christ. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Nothing but a pain from the minute you stepped into my life. You want to go find your bastard baby, go. You want to whine to your invisible brother, go. Leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: My brother is as good as dead to me --

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: And you're dead to me. I like my life simple, you brings nothing but misery. I was better without you. He starts to shove her out the door. She braces herself.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Wait - what are you doing.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Get the hell out of my house, this is my house, I don't want you here. She grabs hold of the sleeve of his checkered jacket.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Everett stop.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You are half a woman, not even that. Get out, and don't come back. He picks her up and hoists her out the door, and slams it behind her. Everett leans on the door, as Maudie knocks on it. He is full of pain and sadness, as he closes his eyes and grits his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud knocks on door repeatedly, as the rain pelts down on 90. 123 124 her. After a few moments, Maud kicks the door, and turns leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud walks down the road in the rain, alone and confused. She's coughing, and exhausted. 125  126 127 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud approaches the steps of Sandra's cottage. Tears stre down her face, and she wipes them away with her little ha She is soaking and frozen. She knocks. Moments later, Sandra comes out on the step.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Maud. What's wrong? Maud hurriedly wipes her face dry, and puts on a brave fa

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Oh. She looks up at Sandra and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought I'd pop in for a visit. Sandra looks at her - a little shocked.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But it's probably not a good time, I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: No. Come. Otherwise I'll be getting drunk by myself in here, so come in. Let's get you warmed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is immersed in the bathtub. Only her eyes and nose a above the water, the rest is completely enveloped by bubb She nervously looks around the brightly lit, cheerily decorated bathroom as Sandra talks from outside the room. Maud doesn't know what to think of it.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is the water warm enough?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Too warm, I'd say. I love it, but you shouldn't be wasting all this hot water. Be a different story if you boiled it. Even then. Don't get me wrong, I love it. My mother used to have long baths. But I coulda just used a wash cloth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 127 128 CONTINUED: 92. 127

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You're not in there to get clean, you're in there to relax. Maud giggles, and continues her nervous chatter.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Can't see me relaxin'. But everything looks so perfect. Almost too perfect. It's lovely, really, but I'm half afraid I'll break something.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Do you like shrimp sandwiches?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I don't need to be that fancy. Not that I don't love em, but bread and butter's just as good. You want me to get out now?

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Stay as long as you like. Maud sinks back down in the water, her eyes still gazing around the room curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is now walking around the immaculate, cozy country h wearing Sandra's mauve coloured housecoat, her head wrapp in a towel. The housecoat drags on the floor, and Maud lo ridiculously out of place. She looks out the window at th clouds in the sky. Sandra is drinking a glass of wine, sitting on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: When I was young, me and my brother would gawk at the clouds. HeвЂ™d see monsters and dungeons. Or guns. IвЂ™d see hearts and puppy dogs. HeвЂ™d get mad at me for turninвЂ™ his nightmares into something simple. ItвЂ™s not that I couldnвЂ™t see monsters. But if itвЂ™s a game, and if the rule is we get to choose to see what we want, why make it dark and dreary? Sandra smiles, charmed by MaudвЂ™s simple wisdom. (CONTINUED)
SANDRA (CONTвЂ™D) Come to New York with me.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Nah. Wouldn't like it.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You could have an actual career Maud. As an artist. I could help you. Maud smiles awkwardly.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That's a word Everett would have no time for. Career. Sounds too fancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is sitting down to a meal by himself. Lonely in h little house. He stares around the room, seeing MaudвЂ™s paintings all over the walls. Very lonely. He gets up and storms out of the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is now dressed. Staring off into space. Sandra sees that Maudie is bothered.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: When I'm mad at someone, I find it helpful to let it out. Maud says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It feels good. Watch. Sandra pours herself another glass of wine, takes a gulp then...

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ahhhhhhhhh! Maud is startled by this aggression. Sandra composes hers

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: No thanks. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 130 Sandra takes another swig of wine. 130 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: 131A
dialogues.text: 132 CONTINUED: (2) 94. 130

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: My husband Jacob is an arrogant pompous know-it-all, his voice is like nails on a chalkboard, I am sick of his feet, I'm sick of his breath, I'm sick of his stttt-uuupid face. She looks at Maud, relieved.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Ahhhh. Now your turn. Maud chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go ahead. I know you're mad at him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Nah. Not like that. Sandra holds up the bottle of wine.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Then you need more wine. Maud pauses for a moment, then holds out her glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is cutting the weeds around his house, aggitated. Impatient. *

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sandra and Maud now sit on the swing on the front porch, their feet kicked up. Maud is now piss eyed drunk. So is Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Um...He's a complainer -

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Let it out. Come on. He's a bastard.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: He's cranky. He's mean. But he's sweet in his own way -

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: You're doing it again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: He gets mad if I donвЂ™t, if I paints all day heвЂ™s mad, if I donвЂ™t paint all day heвЂ™s mad, no pleasinвЂ™ im. But I miss him.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Maud you aren't playing right. She hiccups.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I gotta go to bed, I feel like I might heave up. Sandra watches her go, then pours herself another glass o wine. She stares up at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett lies on his side of the bed, staring at MaudвЂ™s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is down on the wharf with Frank, gutting fish. Fr notices Everett seems different.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Something up, Pal?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: She left me.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Oh well. About time. Frank smiles, teasingly.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Stop. Stop your wise cracking. Everett slits open another fish, and hauls the guts out, then flicks his hand into the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If someone had a baby and they give up to another family, around here, how would I go about finding out who it was give up to? Frank processes this for a second. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 134 135 CONTINUED: 96. 134

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: How in the hell would I know? Everett starts to walk away, frustrated. Frank feels for him. He calls after him.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Everett. You grew up in the poor house, you still do work for them sometimes don't ya?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Mr. Hill died fifteen years ago.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Higgins is there, he'd help you. There's still records there, or paper work or something.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You think they'd know?

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: It's the orphanage. If someone gave up a baby around here, they'd know what happened to it. Everett nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a knock on the door. Sandra answers it. ItвЂ™s EVERETT.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Looking for my woman.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Maud? Maud stands up, secretly delighted to see him. She goes t the door.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Get your things and come on.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Why should I, when you talk to me like that? Maud stands firmly, playing tough. He grabs her by the ar and starts to haul her out the door. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop it! Sandra intervenes.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Hey!!! Let her GO!!!

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: YouвЂ™re coming home!!!

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Leave me ALONE Everett! Maud is furious, Everett is taken aback. Embarrassed, he marches out the door and down over the steps. Maud, still spittinвЂ™ mad, follows him out on the step.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't know why you can't be nice for once in your miserable old life. He stops and turns to her, then finally lets his guard do

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: For crying out loud, woman. Maud looks at him, winded and frustrated, but concedes. 136 EXT. SANDRAвЂ™S SUMMER HOME - BACK YARD - DAY 136 Maud and Everett both awkwardly sit on the hammock.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: YouвЂ™d never last here. YouвЂ™d have to walk seven miles to the store.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Well IвЂ™m not one of your old dogs.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: No cuz at least they knew how to listen. They did what they were told.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m better than a dog.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Maybe. Bigger pain in the ass too. Silence. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 136 CONTINUED: 98. 136

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m more than that. I want you to say it. Everett lies back in the hammock, staring at the sky. The changing shape of the hammock unsteadies Maud and she fal back on him. She starts to get up, but he puts his arm ar her, keeping her by his side.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: (whispering) YouвЂ™re more than that. He holds her there for a moment. He takes a deep breath. Calming himself. They stare up at the clouds. Maud lights up a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That cloud looks like a rabbit. Everett shrugs. Maud decides to quiz him.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you see? Everett stares at the sky for a moment longer.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Clouds.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You can see more than that. Try. Everett looks at her skeptically, then back up at the sky

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I sees a woman. With a big arse. A few teeth missinвЂ™. Maud laughs. Despite herself. EVERETT (CONTвЂ™D) (CONT'D) Bald on the one side of her head. She laughs harder. EVERETT (CONTвЂ™D) (CONT'D) SheвЂ™s in her old manвЂ™s drawers. Maud playfully shoves him as she laughs even harder. (CONTINUED)
EVERETT (CONTвЂ™D) (CONT'D) Foolish are you. ThatвЂ™s your job Maudie. I sees whatвЂ™s there, you sees what could be there.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Kinda how you sees me as something to own. I sees me as your wife. Everett unfolds his arms.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I sees you as my wife, miss. Always did. Didn't want you to leave me.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Why would I leave you?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: You could find better than me.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I got everything I want with you Ev. Everything. 137 EXT. SANDRAвЂ™S SUMMER HOME - DAY 137 Everett is putting Maud's things into his truck as she sa goodbye to Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: Now I have no excuse not to go back home to my boring husband.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Go on. Maud smiles at Sandra.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're my only friend. You know that? Since momma died. Maud smiles at Sandra. Maud heads to towards the truck, a Everett helps her to get in. Sandra watches, thoughtfully as Maud and Everett drive down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Everett and Maud drive down the road, he turns onto a road that she doesn't recognize. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Why we going up here? He says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where we going Ev? Tight-lipped, he keeps driving. Eventually, he pulls off onto the side of the road. The Street is lined with nice, modest little bungalows. He stares ahead, she looks at hi a little confused.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What are we doing here, Ev? He takes a breath, and exhales.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Her house is there. The white one.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Her. Your girl. Maud looks on, in disbelief. She sees the house where he pointing.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: She lives in there? My baby?

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: She's a woman now. Maud nervously opens the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Maud walks up the street, she sees KAY (late 20's), a slight, attractive young woman, out doing gardening, wear a bright pink sun hat. A young man comes out.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: A little. I think I'll make something with the raspberries for dessert. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Maud watches with overwhelming delight as Kay smiles at h husband. Maud studies her hands. Her feet. Her face. She is beautiful and perfect. Maud can hardly take her eyes o her. She decides to walk past them. Maud hobbles along the side of the road, getting closer t the couple

dialogues.speaker: PAUL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm going to wash up for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll be in shortly. Maud observes them, without looking up. But she studies t young woman out of the corner of her eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett sits in the truck, his eyes closed. Working even harder to steady his breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud slows down as she is in front of the house, she bend down and picks a pebble out of her boot. Maud watches Kay through the fence, now almost being eye eye. The RASPBERRY BUSH is between them. At this exact moment, Kay eyes one of the berries, as Maud eyes the oth Together they both take a raspberry off the bush and EAT savouring the taste. Kay is so preoccupied with the berries, she doesn't even notice Maud. Maud smiles watching her, thenвЂ™ stands up and continues past the house, without looking back. As she walks toward Everett, she smiles. Sitting in the truck, he beams a smi back at her.  142 143 144 102.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett and Maud lie in bed, only lit by moonlight. He ca sleep. Neither can she.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I couldn't believe it was her. But I knew it was her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wide, open landscape surrounding Everett's house, as Everett, older, more stooped, carries wood into his house The paint on the house has faded with time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett walks into the house and dumps the wood by the st as The DOCTOR continues doing a check up on Maud.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'm more concerned with the state of my arthritis then my lungs. It's getting harder and harder to hold a paintbrush. Ev thinks I should strap the brush onto my hands. He's holding the stethoscope to her back.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Breathe. She does. It's labored.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You haven't given up smoking yet have you?

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I gives it up sometimes. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: You have Emphysema Maud. You can't smoke.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: She won't be smoking again, I tell you that. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: And air this place out a bit Everett. The air's too thick. Everett walks the doctor to the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fewer paintings outside. Maud comes out of the house, gathers her unsold paintings for the night and takes them inside. Her breathing is a little laboured. She seems tired.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You coming to bed, Maudie? Maud tries to go upstairs, but she canвЂ™t hoist herself She goes over to Everett's chair and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'll be up in a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud wakes up to Everett hovering over her on the chair.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™s wrong with you? Maud wakes up for a moment, she is not feeling so good.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Guess I fell asleep.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I've had enough of this! Falling asleep, up all night coughing, lounging around the house, you don't paint anymore you does nothing. Now smarten up and get lively! She tries to smile.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I'll get up in a minute. Come sit by me Ev. Everett can't hide his concern as he sits next to her on floor. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should get more dogs. Less lonely with dogs.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Don't need dogs, I got you.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Still. Be nice if you had more dogs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud sits in a chair outside as Everett displays her pain there are less than before. Maud is getting to be too tir and ill to paint as much as she used to. But there are st some paintings, and some visitors, admiring them. Maud doesn't really engage in conversation, but then she looks up and sees KAY AND PAUL approaching her house. She watches carefully as Kay weaves through the crowd, admiring MaudвЂ™s paintings. After a few moments, Maud hurriedly goes into the house. Then, she comes out, holding the painting of the girl in pink dress. Maud looks around for Kay, unable to find her at first. B then she sees her and approaches her with the painting.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Bit chilly today. Kay looks up and smiles brightly at Maud.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: Oh, hello. Your paintings are so cheerful and optimistic. Kay smiles at the work.

dialogues.speaker: KAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I like that you ignore the shadows. Maud smiles, unable to think of what to say. Finally she holds out the painting.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You might like this one. Kay studies it for a long time. Maud watches Kay proudly. Kay seems almost speechless. Her face is serious. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: I need this painting. I love it. Maud smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Have it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: How much do I owe you? Maud shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: You donвЂ™t owe me for that, take it.

dialogues.speaker: KAY
dialogues.text: No no, you canвЂ™t give it away. How much? Maud sees Everett walking towards her. She speaks quietly

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I think that little girl is you. Please take it. She smiles at Kay. Kay smiles back, somehow understanding She takes the painting and walks away. Maud discreetly tries to keep her eye on Kay as she climb into the car. She watches, fixated, as the car pulls off the side of the road and drives off into the distance. Everett stands by her for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud sits at her table painting, her work only half finis She works quietly. Then without warning, she suddenly BUR into tears. She lets herself cry, and after a moment she flops over on the table, onto her painting. She cries and cries. Then she gets up. The paint from her picture now on the side of her face and her shirt. She looks at her ruined painting, wipes away her tears and starts to fix it. Everett is up in bed, Maud still sits at her table, stari out the window into the black, quiet night. She wipes the paint off of her face and her shirt with an old wet rag. Then Maud hoists herself out of the chair and heads towar the ladder. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her foot slips on a rung, and Maud tumbles over and falls the ground.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What's going on down there? Everett pokes his head down to see what has happened, and sees Maud laid out on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank and Everett CARRY in a little day bed, as Maud sits feebly, at her table.

dialogues.speaker: FRANK
dialogues.text: Back your end in there, Ev.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: That's lovely. Lovely.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Watch out. Everett lays his end down, and they squeeze the day bed i the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud now lays back on a DAY BED that has been squeezed in the small home. Her things have been rearranged downstair She paints a painting from her bed. She's slower now. Sti thoughtful, but there is less joy in it. Everett brings h a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Some housemaid I became.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: The only one applied for the job. Everett gives her a slight smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett comes downstairs and stokes the fire. Maud is asleep on the couch, her breathing is sounding increasingly laboured.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Maudie? You alright? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Everett goes over to see her, and realizes she isnвЂ™t ve 152 responsive.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maud. She tries to open her eyes and speak

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Ev.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett has Maud bundled up in a blanket and carries her the truck. He lays her in the passenger seat, then gets i the truck. They speed away down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive down the road, Maud tries to speak but canвЂ™t Everett is in a panic.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Shut up Miss. DonвЂ™t go tryinвЂ™ to speak til the DoctorвЂ™s see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they wheel Maudie away, Everett is frantic. He runs up to the nurse with money in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Here, look, ten dollars, just make sure she's alright.

dialogues.speaker: NURSE
dialogues.text: Sir, we don't need your money -

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Take it take it. Just go look after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maud is hooked up to tubes in the hospital bed, Everett i by her side. She is more alert now. She reaches out to touch Everett, but heвЂ™s too far away. He moves in close

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: I knew you were getting sicker, every time I'd ask you, you'd lie to me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He sits on the edge of her bed. She slowly, feebly traces the outline of the rose on his arm. He gently strokes her face. EVERETT (CONTвЂ™D) (CONT'D) You got beautiful eyes Maud Lewis. Maud smiles feebly, flattered. He points to her chest.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So much beauty in there, itвЂ™s spillinвЂ™ out your two peepers. Sometimes I look at them eyes, I think the sun is shining in my face.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: It's true. I look at your face and I can't believe I ever thought you weren't perfect. She reaches over with her gnarled up hand, and struggles outstretch her fingers. She wraps them around his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I wish...I wish I was better at looking after you, everyone always had to be looking after me.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: Shut up. You looked after me. You looked after me. He points to his heart, as he fights back tears. EVERETT (CONTвЂ™D) (CONT'D) You looked after me Miss. Now gimme five more years. She вЂњshhhhвЂ™sвЂќ him. She pulls him in closer to her f

dialogues.speaker: MAUD
dialogues.text: I know you love me Ev.

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We didn't have the things people think you need in order to be lovable. But yet we had love. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 156 157 158 159 CONTINUED: (2) 109. Maud is fading. 156

dialogues.speaker: MAUD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who woulda thought two odd socks would make such a perfect pair He looks at her pleadingly, but she closes her eyes and f away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is trying to start his truck. It wonвЂ™t start. H punches the steering wheel.

dialogues.speaker: EVERETT
dialogues.text: God DAMN stupid truck. He gets out of the truck and lifts up the hood. He fiddle around with it, trying to fix it. Swallowing all his emotions. He gets back in the truck, tries again. This time, it starts. He pulls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett is home by himself. The brightly painted, jam-pac little house feels empty. Everett sits in MaudвЂ™s chair paints a little вЂњMaud-likeвЂќ painting on a card. He pa dogs. Nowhere near her detail or charm. He stops and stares at her paintings on the wall. The lit chicken. So cheerful. So happy. He reaches out and touche the bird. Then turns back to the painting. He scrapes the paintbrush on an old sardine tin, thick with MaudвЂ™s pai Then he signs the card "Everett Lewis". He stares at it long and hard, his eyes filling with tears. Having a seco thought, he PAINTS over the name. He looks out the window. No cars. No visitors. Nothing. He looks back to the painting, and once again paints her name on the board. Then he THROWS the paintbrush across t room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett sits outside his house, with paintings propped up against the house, to sell. His poor knock-offs, which la Maud's care or detail. He stares off into space as a coup of stragglers walk around looking at the art work, the fa paintings on the walls. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Then suddenly SANDRA pulls up. She gets out of her car. She stares at Everett. He looks sad, and incomplete. She stands at a distance for a moment. Then finally walks towards him. Then she sits down next to Everett.

dialogues.speaker: SANDRA
dialogues.text: I missed the funeral. He doesn't look at her. She doesn't look at him. They jus sit in silence together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everett walks into the house. Everywhere he looks, everyw he rests his eyes, there is the hand of Maud. He sits down on the day bed. He kicks off his boots and pulls off a sock. He stares at his feet, one sock on, one sock off. He runs his hand along the empty space of Maud' bed, before clutching her pillow. Then, he looks out the window, and looks up at the clouds Suddenly, he's able to see the clouds take shape: a cheer puppy dog, surrounded by white puffy flowers. As we fade out... Everett Lewis died in 1979, nine years after Maud, in the little 13x13 home. This little house can be found at a permanent exhibit at Nova Scotia Art Gallery in Halifax, Nova Scotia...
